docs.lead_paragraph: MY husband is about to lose his best buddy at work. Bob is leaving, off to great new adventures, and when he leaves, an important beat in the rhythm of Bruce's day will leave, too. Workplace friendships are a crossbreed of the species, sturdy yet fragile at the same time. They start out as lunch and evolve into loyalty. As Laura Senturia, an account executive with Schwartz Communications in Waltham, Mass., says about her colleague, Marybeth McLean Roberts: ''Somewhere along the way, 'Marybeth from work' became simply 'Marybeth.' '' It is a transition that comes with a lot of warning labels. There are small land mines to worry about, such as what to do when your best friend gets your promotion, and the more prosaic risk that you become one of those people who talk about nothing but shop over what is supposed to be a social dinner. ''It's like an office romance without the romance,'' jokes Karen Wright, who works in fund-raising and communications at Minnesota State University in Mankato with her close friend, Ann Rosenquist Fee. The two women sing together in a folk band after hours. On top of that, Ms. Fee's husband and Ms. Wright's significant other are professors at the same university (which is how Ms. Wright began dating him in the first place).
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin column on friendships that form among co-workers and the effort needed to preserve them under strains of workplace and after career paths diverge; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Only about one in five diabetics takes regular doses of aspirin to help prevent heart disease, even though people with diabetes are at much greater risk of developing it, a new study has found. Diabetics are two to four times as likely to develop heart disease as those without diabetes, the American Diabetes Association reports. A person with Type 2 diabetes has the same risk of a heart attack as a nondiabetic who has had an attack.
docs.abstract: Study finds only about one in five diabetics takes regular doses of aspirin to help prevent heart disease, even though people with diabetes are at much greater risk of developing it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The most famous unseen hair in popular music belongs, without question, to Erykah Badu. When her first album, ''Baduizm,'' appeared in 1997, she wrapped her hair in tall cylinders of African-patterned fabric, turning concealment into a crown. Now, stepping on to the shiny set of the Black Entertainment Television cable network's Top 10 countdown show, ''106 and Park,'' Ms. Badu reveals a new invisible hairdo: she has recently shaved her head. With her almond eyes, high forehead, long cheekbones and broad lips, she looks more than ever like a Benin mask. Late last year Ms. Badu released her second studio album, ''Mama's Gun'' (Motown), and her performance on BET last week was a warm-up for a cross-country tour that started on Saturday in Cleveland and arrives at Radio City Music Hall on Valentine's Day. The album title, she said, is a metaphor.

headline.main: Unwrapping a New Era; Erykah Badu Gets On With the Business of Creating Herself

docs.abstract: Interview with singer Erykah Badu, who has begun cross-country tour; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Reverse discrimination may well legally describe the displacement of male doctors specializing in ob-gyn by female practitioners in that specialty (front page, Feb. 7). But from a sociological perspective, the transition suggests the evolution of a new consciousness among women in medicine and among those who seek gynecological care. One's choice of a doctor in this field of women's health is more than a personal matter. It is influenced by an affirmation of gender differences and the changing social image of women who are medical doctors and those who are patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Women's Health Is No Longer a Man's World'' (front page, Feb. 7): The suggestion by male doctors in your article about men in gynecology that their experiences compare to the discrimination against minorities and women in the work force is disingenuous at best. Women who prefer female doctors do not do so from arbitrary prejudice against men. And it is not because they think that men are bad doctors or do not belong in this medical field.

docs.lead_paragraph: I teach my students to spot emotional verbiage and to separate fact from fiction in regard to any scientific claims. A case in point was a Jan. 28 letter to the editor dismissing a Jan. 4 letter-writer's remarks about a connection between abortion and breast cancer. Saying that to assert such a connection ''saddened,'' ''angered and disgusted'' her, the Jan. 28 writer supports her opinion with vague reference to the secondhand opinions of unnamed ''scientists of note.'' Of note is that the Jan. 4 writer cited published medical journal studies, including a 1996 study that was published by my group in the British Medical Association's epidemiology journal. We reported a 30 percent average increase in breast cancer risk among women who had chosen abortion. Increased risk after abortion has now been reported in 13 of 14 studies on American women, including a 90 percent risk increase among New York women, reported by the state Department of Health in 1989.

headline.main: Breast Cancer Link To Abortion Exists

docs.abstract: City University of New York Prof Joel Brind, responding to January 4 and January 28 letters, holds his research shows there is link between abortion and breast cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: POETS, lyricists and lovers are not alone in their fascination with sex. Researchers have long sought to shed light on its mysteries, bringing scientific techniques to bear on the varieties of human sexual behavior. The century's most famous sex-survey researcher, the biologist Alfred C. Kinsey, published his best-selling books on male and female sexual behavior in 1948 and 1953, summarizing data from more than 200,000 punchcards of coded interviews (please, no pregnant chad jokes). Although Kinsey's statistical sampling techniques left much to be desired, he was quite successful in getting both individual respondents and the nation at large to talk about formerly taboo sexual topics.

headline.main: Word for Word/Who's Asking?; Everything Researchers Ever Wanted to Know About Sex

docs.abstract: Word for Word column excerpts questions from various sex surveys conducted by American researchers since 1892; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Arlene Eisenberg, who with her two daughters wrote ''What to Expect When You're Expecting,'' which became known as the pregnancy bible, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 66. The cause was breast cancer, her family said.

headline.main: Arlene Eisenberg, 66, Author Of 'What to Expect' Guides
